meanings.definition: Leave quickly, typically in a hurry or due to an emergency.
meanings.sent1: When the storm hit, we had to bugout from the beach to seek shelter.
meanings.sent2: During the fire drill, the students bugout of the school building in an orderly manner.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel decided to bugout of the tree when it saw a big dog approaching.
meanings.sent4: As soon as the alarm sounded, the workers bugout of the factory like a swarm of bees.
meanings.sent5: The superhero had to bugout from the scene to save the city from disaster.

meanings.definition: A sudden departure or evacuation, especially in response to a crisis.
meanings.sent1: The bugout of the residents from the flood zone was swift and organized.
meanings.sent2: The military conducted a bugout from the war-torn area to ensure the safety of the troops.
meanings.sent3: The bugout of the team from the competition surprised everyone.
meanings.sent4: The bugout of the passengers from the sinking ship was chaotic.
meanings.sent5: The bugout of the animals from the burning forest was a heartbreaking sight.

meanings.definition: To flee or escape from a dangerous situation.
meanings.sent1: The rabbit had to bugout from the fox to save itself.
meanings.sent2: People may bugout from a burning building to avoid harm.
meanings.sent3: The cat decided to bugout from the vet's office as soon as it saw the needle.
meanings.sent4: The explorer had to bugout from the jungle when a storm approached.
meanings.sent5: The hiker had to bugout from the mountain due to an incoming avalanche.
